title: Installing Metropolis Fonts
text: optimal performance avoid plot dimension changes, recommend installing Metropolis system font. Either download Metropolis font https://fontsource.org/fonts/metropolis install using standard OS tool. Alternatively, font files included MSUthemes package inst/fonts/metropolis_5.1.0/. following instructions enable install Metropolis system font. Locate font files: R, run system.file("fonts/metropolis_5.1.0", package = "MSUthemes") find directory Open Finder navigate directory Select .ttf files Double-click font file click “Install Font” Font Book Restart R/RStudio/VS Code Locate font files: R, run system.file("fonts/metropolis_5.1.0", package = "MSUthemes") find directory Open File Explorer navigate directory Select .ttf files Right-click select “Install” (“Install users” available) Restart R/RStudio/VS Code Locate font files: R, run system.file("fonts/metropolis_5.1.0", package = "MSUthemes") find directory Copy .ttf files ~/.fonts/ (create directory doesn’t exist): Restart R/RStudio/VS Code don’t install Metropolis system font, package automatically use via showtext package, may cause slight changes plot dimensions.

text: can install {MSUthemes} package CRAN using: can install development version GitHub though might stable CRAN version: load {MSUthemes} package : R [@RTeam2021] programming language popular statistical computing graphics. many packages R can used create data visualisations, don’t aim cover . Instead, address common methods: built-base R graphics, {ggplot2} package [@Wickham2016a]. R built-graphics capabilities allow users make wide range data visualisations without installing additional packages. Styling Base R Graphics blog post Jumping Rivers [@JR2018] provides nice overview style graphics created base R. Example: changing bar plot colours base R. bars, lines, points, etc. colour, can set col argument one MSU colours. options : msu_red, msu_blue, msu_green, msu_orange, msu_yellow.   Bar plot bars coloured Michigan State University (MSU) green. colours plot based values data, can set default colours using palette() function. Within {MSUthemes}, set_msu_palette() function changes default colours used. currently three palettes available {MSUthemes}, although hope add future. options msu_qual1, msu_div, msu_seq.    Another version barplot showing colours msu_qual1 palette. Run palette("default") reset original base R colours. Example: changing styling base R plots. Within plot() function (related base R plotting functions barplot(), hist()) , arguments control non-data elements plot look. example, family argument changes font family used. can also set many arguments globally calling par() function. Within {MSUthemes}, function set_msu_par() sets default options, including text alignment font base R plots. also recommend adding reference lines using abline() function.   Scatter plot showing base R styling implemented set_msu_par(). Base-R provides ability quickly simply construct initial plots understand data results interest. -depth plots displaying desired refined information interest best constructed using {ggplot2}.1 following examples demonstrate use MSU Big Ten colour palettes using historical institutional data. ggplot2 documentation illustrates create various types plots. Within ggplot2: Elegant Graphics Data Analysis (3e) book, information changing colours refinement {ggplot2} visualisations, provided Hadley Wickham, Danielle Navarro, & Thomas Lin Pedersen[@Wickham2016a].2 Recipe-focused examples available Cookbook R Winston Chang R Cookbook, 2nd Edition James (JD) Long & Paul Teetor3. Let’s set basic MSU Big Ten datasets make plots {ggplot2}. Example: changing non-mapped colours {ggplot2}. {ggplot2}, colour (color) argument changes colour outlining element, fill changes colour filling element. , e.g., bars, lines, points colour, can set either fill colour arguments one MSU colours. options : msu_red, msu_blue, msu_green, msu_orange, msu_yellow.   Bar plot bars coloured yellow. Example: using discrete colour scale {ggplot2}. working qualitative (discrete) data, best palette use "msu_qual1". palette currently contains four colours. Discrete (fill) scale: scale_fill_msu_d()   Bar plot colours msu_qual1. Discrete (colour) scale: scale_colour_msu_d()   Scatter plot colours msu_qual2. Example: using continuous colour scale {ggplot2}. Continuous colour scales may sequential diverging. working sequential (continuous) data, best palette use "msu_seq". Continuous (fill) scale: scale_fill_msu_c()   Bar plot showing sequential green colour palette. Continuous (colour) scale: scale_colour_msu_c()   Scatter plot showing sequential green colour palette. working diverging (continuous) data, best palette use "msu_div". Continuous (fill) scale: scale_fill_msu_c()   Bar plot showing diverging red blue palette. want centre diverging scale around different value, can alternatively pass pre-defined colours {MSUthemes} scale_fill_gradient2() {ggplot2}:   Bar plot showing diverging orange purple palette centred median undergraduate population Big Ten institutions. Example: changing theme {ggplot2}. Within {ggplot2}, themes allow control appearance non-data elements plot. default theme theme_grey() darker background. recommend using white transparent background, created theme_minimal() theme_bw(). can also use theme_MSU() {MSUthemes} additionally sets plot font Metropolis (used MSU branding). Check already run library(MSUthemes) ensure fonts load correctly.   Bar plot styled theme_MSU(). {MSUthemes} package includes comprehensive color support Big Ten institutions, making easy create multi-institutional comparisons consistent, recognizable branding. Example: comparing Big Ten institutions institutional colors.   Scatter plot comparing Big Ten institutions using official colors. find bug {MSUthemes} package, something isn’t working quite expected, please submit GitHub issue. col = msu_green,         main = "MSU Graduation Rate (1997 - 2023)",         xlab = "Graduation Year of Incoming Class", ylab = "6-Year Graduation Rate") set_msu_palette("msu_qual1") plot(1:13, 1:13, col=1:13, pch=19, cex=3, xlab="", ylab="",      main = "Example of Michigan State University (MSU) Colour Palette Plot",      sub = "Source: Sequential Values") abline(h=1:13, v=1:13, col = "lightgrey") set_msu_par() barplot(C150_4 ~ entry_term, data=filter(BigTen, name == "MSU"),         col = set_msu_palette("msu_qual1"),         main = "MSU Graduation Rate (1997 - 2023)",         xlab = "Graduation Year of Incoming Class", ylab = "6-Year Graduation Rate") set_msu_par() plot(1:13, 1:13, col=1:13, pch=19, cex=3, xlab="", ylab="",      main = "Example of Michigan State University (MSU) Colour Palette Plot",      sub = "Source: Sequential Values") abline(h=1:13, v=1:13, col = "lightgrey") library(ggplot2) library(dplyr)  set_msu_par()  ## reset graphics par(ameters)  MSU_df <- filter(BigTen, name == "MSU") ggplot(data = MSU_df,        mapping = aes(x = entry_term, y = UGDS)) +   geom_col(fill = msu_yellow) ggplot(data = slice(MSU_df, 1:13),        mapping = aes(x = entry_term, y = UGDS, fill = factor(entry_term))) +   geom_col() +   scale_fill_msu_d(palette = "msu_qual1") ggplot(data = slice(MSU_df, 1:4),        mapping = aes(x = entry_term, y = UGDS, colour = factor(entry_term))) +   geom_point(size = 6) +   scale_colour_msu_d(palette = "msu_qual2") ggplot(data = slice(MSU_df, 1:13),        mapping = aes(x = entry_term, y = UGDS, fill = UGDS)) +   geom_col() +   scale_fill_msu_c(palette = "msu_seq") ggplot(data = MSU_df,        mapping = aes(x = entry_term, y = UGDS, colour = UGDS)) +   geom_point(size = 6) +   scale_colour_msu_c(palette = "msu_seq") ggplot(data = MSU_df,        mapping = aes(x = entry_term, y = UGDS, fill = UGDS)) +   geom_col() +   scale_fill_msu_c(palette = "msu_div") ggplot(data = MSU_df,        mapping = aes(x = entry_term, y = UGDS, fill = UGDS)) +   geom_col() +   scale_fill_gradient2(low = msu_orange,                        high = msu_purple,                        midpoint = median(MSU_df$UGDS, na.rm = TRUE)) BigTen_2023 <- filter(BigTen, entry_term == 2023)  ggplot(data = BigTen_2023, aes(x = reorder(name, UGDS), y = UGDS, fill = ADM_RATE)) +   geom_col() +   scale_fill_msu_c(palette = "msu_div") +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +   labs(x = NULL,        y = "Undergraduate Enrollment",        title = "Big Ten Enrollment (2023)",        subtitle = "Bars Shaded by Admission Rate",        fill = "Admission Rate") +   theme_MSU() +   theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1)) BigTen_2023 <- filter(BigTen, entry_term == 2023)  ggplot(data = BigTen_2023,        aes(x = ADM_RATE, y = C150_4, size = UGDS, colour = name, label = name)) +   geom_point(alpha = 0.7) +   ggrepel::geom_text_repel(size = 3,                            colour = "black",                            show.legend = FALSE, max.overlaps = 20) +   scale_x_continuous(labels = scales::percent) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent) +   scale_colour_manual(values = bigten_colors_primary) +   scale_size_continuous(labels = scales::comma, range = c(3, 12)) +   guides(size = guide_legend(title = "Undergraduate\nEnrollment"),          colour = "none") +   labs(x = "Admission Rate",        y = "6-Year Graduation Rate",        title = "Big Ten Institutional Comparison (2023)",        subtitle = "Each institution shown in its official primary color") +   theme_MSU() pdf(file = "MSU-feature-plot.pdf",  # name of file     width = 7,                      # width in inches     height = 5                      # height in inches     ) barplot(C150_4 ~ entry_term, data = filter(BigTen, name == "MSU"),         col = msu_green,         main = "MSU Graduation Rate (1997 - 2023)",         xlab = "Graduation Year of Incoming Class",         ylab = "6-Year Graduation Rate") dev.off() # Create a plot p <- ggplot(data = MSU_df, aes(x = entry_term, y = UGDS, fill = UGDS)) +   geom_col() +   scale_fill_msu_c(palette = "msu_seq") +   labs(title = "MSU Undergraduate title: MSU Themes and Color Palettes
text: MSUthemes package provides colour palettes themes Michigan State University (MSU) comprehensive colour support Big Ten Conference institutions. package includes MSU-specific palettes (sequential, diverging, qualitative) designed align MSU’s branding guidelines, uses Metropolis font (MSU’s chosen font) construction plots, well primary secondary colour palettes 18 Big Ten institutions, making ideal multi-institutional comparisons collaborative research visualizations using ggplot2. package inspired RSSthemes package based work Andreas Krause, Nicola Rennie, Brian Tarran. original RSSthemes package focused Royal Statistical Society (RSS) branding, package adapts concepts fit MSU’s visual identity. MSUthemes package uses RSSthemes framework, replaces RSS colour palettes font MSU colour palettes font, respectively, adds comprehensive Big Ten Conference institutional colours reliable institution--colour matching capabilities. authors RSSthemes package created excellent website discussing ‘Best Practices Data Visualisation’, published Royal Statistical Society. RSS companion website great resource anyone interested data visualization provides valuable insights effective data communication. MSUthemes package aims bring best practices MSU community, helping users create visually appealing informative graphics mirror MSU’s branding guidelines.

title: MSU Themes and Color Palettes
text: MSU colour palettes provided within MSUthemes based official MSU branding guidelines, can found : https://brand.msu.edu/visual/color-palette. official MSU colour palettes include primary colours green white, well secondary colours black, silver, gray, accent colours. MSUthemes package includes several MSU palette types: Sequential palettes: msu_seq, msu_seq_red, msu_seq_blue, etc. Diverging palettes: msu_div Qualitative palettes: msu_qual1, msu_qual2 Individual MSU colours also available constants (e.g., msu_green, msu_orange, msu_teal, msu_grellow).

title: MSU Themes and Color Palettes
code: library(ggplot2) library(dplyr) library(MSUthemes)  # Filter MSU data from the included BigTen dataset MSU_df <- filter(BigTen, name == "MSU")  # MSU sequential palette - showing enrollment trends ggplot(MSU_df,        aes(x = entry_term, y = UGDS, fill = UGDS)) +   geom_col() +   scale_fill_msu_c(palette = "msu_seq") +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +   scale_fill_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +   labs(title = "MSU Undergraduate Enrollment Over Time",        x = "Entry Term",        y = "Undergraduate Enrollment") +   theme_MSU() +   theme(legend.position = "right") # MSU qualitative palette - comparing recent cohorts ggplot(slice(MSU_df, 2:14),        aes(x = factor(entry_term), y = C150_4, fill = factor(entry_term))) +   geom_col() +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent) +   scale_fill_msu_d(palette = "msu_qual1", guide = "none") +   labs(title = "MSU 6-Year Graduation Rates",        x = "Entry Term",        y = "Graduation Rate (Percentage, %)",        fill = "Entry Term") +   theme_MSU()

what: Using Big Ten Colours for Multi-Institutional Comparisons
title: MSU Themes and Color Palettes
text: MSUthemes package provides three methods using Big Ten institutional colours: Method 1: Named vectors specific institutions (recommended) ensures exact colour matching regardless data order:  Method 2: Helper function error checking  Method 3: Use aggregate palette 18 institutions
code: # Get 2023 data for all Big Ten institutions BigTen_2023 <- filter(BigTen, entry_term == 2023)  ggplot(BigTen_2023,        aes(x = reorder(name, UGDS), y = UGDS, fill = name)) +   geom_col() +   scale_fill_manual(values = bigten_colors_primary, guide = "none") +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +   labs(x = NULL, y = "Undergraduate Enrollment",        title = "Big Ten Institutions Enrollment",        subtitle = "Fall 2023") +   theme_MSU() +   theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1)) # Select specific institutions and get their colours my_institutions <- c("Michigan", "Ohio State", "MSU", "Northwestern") my_colors <- get_bigten_colors(my_institutions, type = "primary")  ggplot(filter(BigTen_2023, name %in% my_institutions),        aes(x = ADM_RATE, y = C150_4, color = name, size = UGDS)) +   geom_point() +   scale_color_manual(values = my_colors) +   scale_x_continuous(labels = scales::percent) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent) +   scale_size_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +   guides(color = guide_legend(nrow = 1, order = 1, override.aes = list(size = 4)),          size = guide_legend(nrow = 1, order = 2)) +   labs(title = "Admission Rate vs Graduation Rate (2023)",        subtitle = "Select Big Ten Institutions",        x = "Admission Rate", y = "6-Year Graduation Rate",        color = "Institution", size = "Enrollment") +   theme_MSU() +   theme(legend.box = "vertical",         legend.direction = "horizontal") ggplot(BigTen_2023, aes(x = reorder(name, UGDS), y = UGDS, fill = name)) +   geom_col() +   scale_fill_msu_d(palette = "bigten_primary") +   labs(title = "2023 Big Ten Undergraduate Enrollment",        x = NULL, y = "Undergraduate Enrollment") +   theme_MSU() +   theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1),         legend.position = "none")

title: MSU Themes and Color Palettes

code: # Focus on Michigan with its official primary colour Michigan_df <- filter(BigTen, name == "Michigan")  ggplot(Michigan_df, aes(x = entry_term, y = UGDS)) +   geom_col(fill = bigten_colors_primary["Michigan"]) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +   labs(title = "University of Michigan Enrollment Trends",        x = "Entry Term",        y = "Undergraduate Enrollment") +   theme_MSU()

title: Big Ten Conference Institutional Data (1996-2023) — BigTen
Big Ten Conference Institutional Data (1996-2023) — BigTen
text: data frame 504 rows 38 variables: name Character. Institution name (e.g., "MSU", "Michigan", "Ohio State") Landgrant.tf Logical. Whether institution land-grant university Public.tf Logical. Whether institution public (TRUE) private (FALSE) AAU.tf Logical. Whether institution member Association American Universities entry_term Numeric. Year data entry corresponds (1996-2023) UGDS Integer. Total undergraduate enrollment ADM_RATE Numeric. Admission rate (proportion applicants admitted) C150_4 Numeric. Completion rate first-time, full-time students (150% expected time) PCTPELL Numeric. Percentage undergraduates receiving Pell grants n.pell Integer. Number undergraduates receiving Pell grants TUITIONFEE_IN Integer. -state tuition fees TUITIONFEE_OUT Integer. --state tuition fees TUITFTE Integer. Net tuition revenue per full-time equivalent student BOOKSUPPLY Integer. Average cost books supplies ROOMBOARD_ON Integer. Average cost room board -campus students OTHEREXPENSE_ON Integer. expenses -campus students OTHEREXPENSE_FAM Integer. expenses students living family CoA.inState Integer. Total cost attendance -state students CoA.outState Integer. Total cost attendance --state students otherCosts.tot Integer. Total costs fte.tot Integer. Total full-time equivalent tuition plus costs fte..rat Numeric. Ratio full-time equivalent tuition plus costs -state total costs UGDS_WHITE Numeric. Proportion white undergraduate students UGDS_BLACK Numeric. Proportion Black undergraduate students UGDS_HISP Numeric. Proportion Hispanic undergraduate students UGDS_ASIAN Numeric. Proportion Asian undergraduate students UGDS_AIAN Numeric. Proportion American Indian/Alaska Native undergraduate students UGDS_NHPI Numeric. Proportion Native Hawaiian/Pacific Islander undergraduate students UGDS_2MOR Numeric. Proportion students two races UGDS_NRA Numeric. Proportion non-resident alien undergraduate students UGDS_UNKN Numeric. Proportion students unknown race/ethnicity UGDS_WHITENH Numeric. Proportion white non-Hispanic undergraduate students UGDS_BLACKNH Numeric. Proportion Black non-Hispanic undergraduate students UGDS_API Numeric. Proportion Asian/Pacific Islander undergraduate students UGDS_AIANOLD Numeric. Proportion American Indian/Alaska Native students (legacy coding) UGDS_HISPOLD Numeric. Proportion Hispanic students (legacy coding) UGDS_MEN Numeric. Proportion male undergraduate students UGDS_WOMEN Numeric. Proportion female undergraduate students

title: Big Ten Conference Institutional Data (1996-2023) — BigTen
text: Compiled multiple institutional federal data sources including Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System (IPEDS) institutional reports. Data spans 1996-2023. dataset subset College Scorecard dataset (https://collegescorecard.ed.gov/data/), focusing Big Ten institutions.

title: Big Ten Conference Institutional Data (1996-2023) — BigTen
text: dataset includes 18 current Big Ten Conference members: Original members: Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Michigan, Minnesota, Northwestern, Ohio State, Purdue, Wisconsin 1990 addition: MSU (Michigan State University) 1993 addition: Penn State 2011 addition: Nebraska 2014 additions: Maryland, Rutgers 2024 additions: UCLA, USoCal (USC), Oregon, Washington Data availability varies year institution. Earlier years (especially 1996-2000) may limited data variables. Financial data demographic breakdowns became standardized complete later years. dataset particularly useful : Longitudinal analysis Big Ten institutions Comparative studies across public vs. private institutions Analysis conference expansion impacts Demographic trend analysis higher education Cost accessibility studies

title: Michigan State University (MSU) Theme — theme_MSU
text: Custom ggplot2 theme

title: Michigan State University (MSU) Theme — theme_MSU
code: theme_MSU(   base_size = 11,   base_family = "Metropolis",   header_family = NULL,   base_line_size = base_size/22,   base_rect_size = base_size/22,   rel_small = 12/14,   rel_tiny = 11/14,   rel_large = 16/14,   ink = "black",   paper = "white",   accent = "#3366FF" )

title: Michigan State University (MSU) Theme — theme_MSU
text: base_size Base font size text elements. Default 12. base_family Font used text elements. Default "Metropolis". header_family Font family titles headers. default, NULL, uses theme inheritance set font. setting affects axis titles, legend titles, plot title tag text. base_line_size Base line size base_size/22 base_rect_size Base rectangle size base_size/22 rel_small Relative size small text (e.g., axis tick labels) rel_tiny Relative size tiny text (e.g., caption) rel_large Relative size large text (e.g., title) ink Text colour. Default "black". paper Background colour. Default "white". accent Accent colour. Default bright blue, "#3366FF"

title: Michigan State University (MSU) Theme — theme_MSU
text: ggplot2 theme

title: Michigan State University (MSU) Theme — theme_MSU
code: library(ggplot2) ggplot(data = mtcars, aes(x = mpg, y = disp, color = wt)) +   geom_point() +   theme_MSU()

See Installing Metropolis Fonts vignette. vignette("install_metropolis_font", package = "MSUthemes") Addresses issue #2 Constructed MSUthemes website using pkgdown. Thank @claude!
